CommentsTitle: Great monitor + 75Hz + HOW TO FIX LOW VOLUME SOUND
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 9, 2020
CommentsContent: This HP 24mh monitor has a clear, crisp display and is the perfect size for desktop use (not too big, not too small).  It accepts both HDMI and DisplayPort inputs (and even VGA for old school PCs).  While Windows will select 60Hz refresh rate by default, you can go into Windows' display settings and select 75Hz refresh rate for this monitor.  The 75Hz refresh rate really does help smooth out motion.  You should also go into the monitor's "Image" menu setting and set Response Time to Level 3 which provides the best VSYNC performance.  One of the best features that places this monitor above and beyond its price range is the 90-degree rotating screen, height adjustment, and swiveling base.  The stand is rock-solid without any wobble.  The speakers are just fine once you discover the menu control I explain below:HOW TO FIX LOW VOLUME SOUND:  The built-in speakers are better than some reviewers indicate.  I believe most people don't discover that the monitor menu has its own volume control that's set to 50% volume by factory default.  If you just connect this monitor to the PC you'll automatically get sound through the HP speakers via HDMI or DisplayPort (you only have to use the separate audio cable when using the VGA input).  But no matter how high you turn up your PC volume control, you'll only get 50% volume from the monitor's speakers which is why people complain about low volume.  To fix this, all you need to do is go to the "Management" tab of the monitor menu, select "Audio", and then turn up the volume control from 50 (default) to 100 and you'll find the monitor speakers are plenty loud.  After that, you'll only have to use your PC volume control as normal.This is a great quality monitor with features beyond its price range.  Fantastic value, HP!ADDITIONAL NOTE:  HP sells an identical monitor to the HP 24mh under the model P24h.  The only difference is that the P24h has a black plastic logo strip along the bottom instead of silver like the 24mh.  Everything else is identical (specs, speakers, height adjustable stand, etc.) plus the P24h comes with both an HDMI cable and a DisplayPort cable.

CommentsTitle: For those who complain about the volume being too low you need to adjust it internally
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 17, 2020
CommentsContent: Overall the price was right and the screen is great. A few people complain about the speakers being too quiet. The built in speakers are pretty good, just don't expect the quality of the speakers to be as good as $100 external speakers. To adjust Speaker Volume on the monitor itself with HDMI connected (this should work with the 3.5 mm male to male cable as well):• Press any of the buttons on the monitor (not the power)• Select the far left menu icon• Press the second from the left button to scroll down to management• Press the far left button to select• Scroll to audio• Press far left button to select• Select volume• Adjust the max range up to 100%. The default is set on 50%Then use the volume control slider on your PC to adjust the volume as you normally would.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 22, 2020
CommentsContent: Bought this screen just this week and it is amazing. Great clarity and good price

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 29, 2020
CommentsContent: I selected this monitor because it has both HDMI and DisplayPort inputs, (it also has VGA, but I'll never use it) has a stand that will rotate to 90, allows for VESA mounting without blocking inputs, is 24" diag. with small bezels, is 1920x1080, and is an established brand. It is all of these, no problem. What you also get is tool-free installation (nice to have even if you have plenty of tools), and cables! I expect a power cord with anything that uses power, but I did not expect an HDMI cable. It did not come with a DisplayPort cable, but I hooked one (of the two I bought) via miniDP, and a full-sized cable would have just gone into the parts pile.  Six-foot HDMI cables are a great item to have laying around.It also came with an 1/8" stereo patch cable for analog audio. I saw the description about speakers, but didn't intend to use that feature. I didn't even hook up the cable. What surprised me was when the monitor I hooked up via HDMI started playing sound from the laptop. This feature does not seem to be mentioned anywhere in this product description, nor even in the user manual, but this thing does HDMI audio extraction! I haven't yet tried, but I think you could hook up a Chromecast and get the full audio/video experience. That said, there does not seem to be much of an amplifier -- it's not loud, even with the volume cranked all the way up on the PC (there is no on-monitor volume control). In any case, it's a nice bonus. I didn't buy this thing for the speakers, but their presence doesn't bother me. The display portion of the monitor is fairly thin. The speakers do add a bit of girth, but no more than you would have from a similarly-featured (no audio) 24" monitor from a few years ago. Same goes for weight. I generally use Dell 24" monitors, and this HP model holds up well against the Dell models that are significantly more expensive (and have not dropped features like VESA mounting and 90 rotating base support).Bottom line: I'm thrilled to get a high quality 24" 1920x1080 monitor with VESA mounting, 90 rotating base, and both HDMI and DisplayPort, and even giddy about the included HDMI cable and speakers, all for $110.

CommentsTitle: Very nice with a great picture! VGA mode is okay...
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 2, 2020
CommentsContent: Set up originally using an HDMI cable and it worked flawlessly! Of course, one of the reasons I chose this monitor is because of the built-in speakers. Unfortunately, the speakers do NOT work with the HDMI cord plugged in. Originally, I thought the speakers just simply didn’t work.I contacted tech support and they had me try a different cord but never asked me about HDMI. So, although she was very nice, she had no idea what she was doing aside from reading a script. They need to add the HDMI issue their script. A note on the site itself might be a good idea as well. Anyway, she set up a return that I later cancelled (they never told UPS that I cancelled so he showed up for a return the next - actually, that was wrong as well since I couldn’t return it till the new one arrived - oh well...)Anyway, after I sat and thought about it for a while, I suspected that the HDMI carrying the audio signal thereby blocking it. So, I used the VGA connection. It works, but I had to significantly adjust the vertical setting on the monitor.Bottom line, the monitor is now fully functional including the speakers. The speakers sound pretty much like any other PC speakers although a tad louder, certainly loud enough for my use. I was able to tweak the sound a bit with the audio manager that came with the Lenovo computer. The point I deducted was for the tech support. I realize this is a new monitor but the people answering the phone should at least understand the technology even if they don’t know the item details.UPDATE 1: The monitor does NOT work well unless I use an HDMI cable, which I am now doing. So, I am back to external speakers. Basically, if I try to use anything other than an HDMI cable, the monitor cuts out (goes dark) frequently, although it does come back on again. BOTTOM LINE: I am not able to use the internal soeakers, perhaps you’ll have better luck...

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 20, 2020
CommentsContent: I purchased this monitor because of the reviews and my 25+ years of experience with HP products. It arrived quickly and undamaged. And for 2-1/2 months it was a good purchase.A few days ago I started noticing that when I switched applications a "ghost" would remain on the screen, visible, behind/below the currently running application. (No, my monitor does not stay turned on to a static screen for hours on end.)Today the problem was so bad I contacted Amazon product support. They were as helpful as they could be, including the CS agent holding for 27 minutes for HP Support to answer the phone..........And then the nightmare began.The first person at HP went through a few troubleshooting steps and said he thought the problem may be the graphics card drivers or the card itself. But, because my desktop is a Lenovo he had to transfer me to an HP agent who could help with a non-HP computer.That person did a few trouble shooting steps (after trying to tell me how to hook up my new printer after I explained the monitor issue) and said that the computer was not the problem, it was the monitor and needed to be resolved as an "in-warranty" issue and transferred me to the HP warranty department for resolution.This new agent, after telling me I could "reset" the monitor by holding the power key for 15 seconds then said that the problem was not a warranty issue and said she was going to transfer me back to the department that had sent me to her. At which point, after almost 90 minutes on the phone with HP and almost 30 before that with Amazon, I lost my feces.So, tomorrow I am going to file a warranty complaint through my credit card company, file a lack of customer service and common sense complaint with HP and start looking for a new monitor - NOT HP!Until this issue I would have given this monitor a 4 or 5 star rating. Not now, it is only a 1 star, a monitor should not start failing in less than 3 months. The customer service experience is a negative 5.

CommentsTitle: Great price, I needed to buy a separate a DisplayPort Cable to get 75hz
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 6, 2020
CommentsContent: For the price, this really can't be beat if you want a new monitor in the home office during month 8+ of COVID-19. Other reviews are incorrect: this DOES come with built-in speakers, which sound fine. My only complaint is that this was advertised as having a 75hz refresh rate, but the HDMI cord this comes with is capable of only 1080p@60hz. Maybe it was just my setup/video card/configuration, but the monitor could handle it and the default cord couldn't! I had to get a DisplayPort cord for an additional $10 and now it does 75hz just fine. Whether I can even tell the difference between 60hz and 75hz is between me and my God, but if you're in the market for a nice new monitor, this is a great choice you won't regret.

CommentsTitle: Get a refund, not a replacement!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 12, 2020
CommentsContent: Within two hours of receiving this monitor, it turned off. And stayed off.  Then when I could get it to turn on again, the screen turned green.  Amazon was awesome and connected me to an HP rep.  She said they would send me a box and label to return the monitor and send a replacement within 10-12 business days.  That is NOT the case.  I contacted them on September 29 and it is now October 12 and still no return box or label.  I followed up and they told me I should receive it by October 14.Next, I was told that they will not ship the replacement until they receive the replacement monitor.  At this rate, I will not get the replacement until November.  When I asked if I could receive a refund instead, they basically said "too late."  With 40+ Zoom meetings between now and then, I will have to buy another monitor to use in the interim.If you get a dud like I did, opt for the refund ASAP.

CommentsTitle: Does not come with DP Cable. Only HDMI. Not 75HZ.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 15, 2020
CommentsContent: So far seems like a great monitor for the price.However, if you think it will come with a DisplayPort cable, *it doesn't*. I had to order the cables and I'm still waiting for them to arrive before I can be able to check the actual performance of the monitors themselves. It does come with a HDMI cable, however.I wish it was a little more clear on the product description, but I guess that could be considered my fault too for not clarifying. Also, as the other reviews have stated, this is *NOT* 75HZ. It's 60HZ! Incorrect description! Since I am using these two as my third & fourth monitors, it isn't that huge of a deal, but for those of you who are looking for 75hz, this is not it.EDIT: if you're looking for clear quality, put in just the little extra bucks to get a better monitor. The text is incredibly blurry, the colors are dull, and in general it's just a subpar monitor when you can get better quality monitors for just a couple bucks more.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 13, 2020
CommentsContent: I bought two of these, and they have been great.  I like the input options, and that the monitors have speakers.  I'm no audiophile, so having simple speakers included in the monitors meant I could have one less item on my desk.I put these on the "Mount it!" dual VESA mount (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B08BW739D2/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1), which was super easy.  The monitors came with a very nice, sturdy, flat-base (So you don't totally lose that desk space!!) stand, but I opted for the mount.  The monitors also came with VESA screws already installed, so mounting them just required removal of the screws and reinstallation of the screws with the VESA mount plate.Also, I have been working from home, and had one these hooked up to both my personal computer and my work computer.  Switching inputs was easy using the hard-key buttons hidden on the bottom-right of the monitor body.And as simple as it is, these came with an HDMI an power cable which were 6ft long each, which was nice.  NOTE: The listing says 75hz refresh rate, but that is with DisplayPort cables.  As I write this, these are running at 60hz on the included HDMI cables.  This doesn't matter at all to me, because I don't play games on them, but FYI!I shop around pretty extensively before making purchases, and I feel confident that these are a good value (obviously, since I bought them).  $110 for a brand-name, 1080p, 60/75hz IPS monitor with speakers, VESA mount-reay but comes with a good stand, and has good input options (HDMI, DP, or VGA).  Now that I've owned them for a few weeks, I would absolutely purchase them again next time.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 28, 2020
CommentsContent: I was excited to get two HP 24mh monitors for my home office. The size and resolution were a good match for my Surface Book. The thin margin on 3 sides makes working across multiple monitors much easier. Unfortunately, neither monitor worked correctly out of the box. One constantly turned itself on and off and the sound wouldn't work on either of them (second monitor started the on/off thing after the third day). HP support was not a good experience. They blamed the PC and Microsoft blamed the monitor. I had to spend several hours with my own IT company trouble-shooting to verify that the problem was with the monitors. HP's virtual assistant does not seem to understand that HP sells monitors apart from computers. HP's technical assistance chat person quickly told me that I had to call a different technical support line for this problem and that there would be a nominal fee for the service. (What!?). I called anyway but got bored waiting and explored Amazon's support (Tokyo rocks!) Return and refund were processed right away and I ordered Dell monitors instead.

CommentsTitle: Excellent monitor but no speakers as advertised
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 1, 2020
CommentsContent: EDIT: it appears this monitor has speakers only compatible with Windows. So semi-correct... can’t for the life of me get it to run through my Mac though...Bought this monitor, as many people probably have, because working from home on my 13" laptop long-term was intolerable. This is a gorgeous monitor, lovely and slimline with an unobtrusive base. It takes a decent amount of real-estate on my desk, but the base is low-profile so I end up setting things on it out of the way. It has a good amount of customizable color balance options. The only drawback I have found is the cables must be run either side of the support which presents a cable management dilemma. Not insurmountable though! For $100 give or take, it's a great monitor, but does not actually have speakers built-in as described, so if that's a deal-breaker for you, heads up.That said, the height and tilt adjustments are nice and solid but not too tough to move around smoothly. As long as the speaker thing doesn't both you, I'd definitely recommend this monitor for a cheap and cheerful posture-saver for WFH!

CommentsTitle: Great monitor with caveat and horrible customer service from HP
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 14, 2020
CommentsContent: Bought this monitor to go side by side with my Samsung 27" (which I've had for over 7 years). Color was beautiful, read review on how to change from default 60 hz refresh rate to 75 hz and all was well until I reached up to tilt it from the top: BEWARE there is almost NO bevel at the top and edges and touching the screen it broke (sent lines across top and down the center). I had only had it for 26 days. Called Amazon and they said to call HP since it was within the 30 days. HP rep said broken screen was not covered and offered to send me a replacement for the exact price as on Amazon (new) and take 8-10 days to get it to me, PLUS return broken one at my own expense. Thanks, but NO thanks. Called Amazon back on day 30 and told them what HP said and they offered a full refund or replacement with 2-day shipping. They asked me to return the broken one at their cost.  The entire phone conversation took 15 minutes. This is why I am still a Prime customer after almost 20 years. They know how to treat customers.This is a fabulous screen for the price and I could find no others on Amazon in this price range with speakers and 75 hz RR. I did take the replacement, which was here as promised 2 days later and returned the broken one the next day.  Just be careful and only hold the screen on the back and bottom, beveled-edge as the least amount of pressure will crack the screen and that is not covered with Amazon's extra warranty through Assurion nor will HP cover it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 14, 2020
CommentsContent: This full-HD monitor is an outstanding value. The image is great, the frame is unobtrusive and nice looking, the stand is solid and stable, and the built-in speakers are perfectly adequate for Zoom, Teams, Skype, or YouTube videos. It supports VGA, HDMI, and DisplayPort inputs. The power is provided by an AC cord, without the bulky and awkward power transformer box that some monitors come with.Normally I don't care much about the menus built into the monitor, but these deserve special recognition. The user interface ("OSD" = On Screen Display) is very well organized, full featured, and easy to use. It even has the ability to reposition the menu and to make it translucent.I purchased this monitor to go along with an inexpensive mini-PC and it is an excellent companion.
